title: Modified Mallampati Classification
description: Stratifies predicted difficulty of endotracheal intubation based on anatomical features visible during oral examination

parameters.name: visible_structures
parameters.description: Anatomical structures visible during oral examination with mouth open and tongue protruded

result.name: mallampati_class
result.description: Modified Mallampati class indicating predicted intubation difficulty

ranges.interpretation: Faucial pillars, soft palate, and uvula visualized. Low risk of difficult intubation.
Faucial pillars and soft palate visualized, but uvula masked by tongue base. Mildly increased intubation difficulty.
Only soft palate visualized. Moderately difficult intubation predicted. Consider alternative strategies.
Soft palate not visualized, only hard palate visible. High risk of difficult intubation. Plan alternative airway management.

references: Mallampati SR, Gatt SP, Gugino LD, Desai SP, Waraksa B, Freiberger D, Liu PL. A clinical sign to predict difficult tracheal intubation: a prospective study. Can Anaesth Soc J. 1985 Jul;32(4):429-34. doi: 10.1007/BF03011357.
Samsoon GL, Young JR. Difficult tracheal intubation: a retrospective study. Anaesthesia. 1987 May;42(5):487-90. doi: 10.1111/j.1365-2044.1987.tb04039.x.

Lee A, Fan LT, Gin T, Karmakar MK, Ngan Kee WD. A systematic review (meta-analysis) of the accuracy of the Mallampati tests to predict the difficult airway. Anesth Analg. 2006 Jun;102(6):1867-78. doi: 10.1213/01.ane.0000217211.12232.ea.
formula: Visual assessment of oropharyngeal structures. Class I: Faucial pillars + soft palate + uvula visible. Class II: Faucial pillars + soft palate visible, uvula masked. Class III: Only soft palate visible. Class IV: Only hard palate visible.
notes: Assessment performed with patient seated upright, mouth open, tongue maximally protruded
Classically performed without phonation (patient should not say 'ah')
Higher classes (III-IV) associated with increased intubation difficulty
Should not be used in isolation but as part of comprehensive airway assessment
Sensitivity 0.51, specificity 0.87 for predicting difficult intubation
Other factors to consider: thick neck (>40 cm), limited neck mobility, small mouth opening (<3 finger breadths)
Additional factors: short thyromental distance (<6 cm), limited mandibular protrusion, history of difficult airway
Also used to predict sleep apnea risk (classes III-IV associated with higher OSA incidence)
Consider video laryngoscopy, fiber-optic intubation, or surgical airway for predicted difficult cases
Mnemonic 'PUSH': Pillars, Uvula, Soft palate, Hard palate (Class I has all visible)
